description: From Middle English obstinate, obstinat, from Latin obstinātus, past participle of obstinō (“set one's mind firmly upon, resolve”), from ob (“before”) + *stinare, from stare (“to stand”). Doublet of ostinato.

adjectives.description: obstinate (comparative more obstinate, superlative most obstinate)

entries.meaning: Stubbornly adhering to an opinion, purpose, or course, usually with implied unreasonableness; persistent.
examples: From this consideration it is that we have derived the custom, in times of war, to punish  […]  those who are obstinate to defend a place that by the rules of war is not tenable  […]

entries.meaning: (of inanimate things) Not easily subdued or removed.
examples: Now it happened that Kasturbai  […]  had again begun getting haemorrhage, and the malady seemed to be obstinate.

entries.meaning: (of a facial feature) Typical of an obstinate person; fixed and unmoving.
